page.title: 10ROADS THROUGH MARLBOROUGH
page.content: A glance down Marlborough High Street would reveal the importance of transport in this town's history, and to a certain extent its present situation. The scattering of inns hotels and tearooms indicates the transitory nature of the crowds of people who use Marlborough as a major stopping point on the main road (A4) between Bath and London. Marlborough's role in transport began in Roman times, when close by was the intersection of Fosse Way and Watling Street. In the 18th.C. it was an overnight stop for the coaches, and travellers were housed in an inn now part of Marlborough College. The Building of the M4 has reduced Marlborough's role in transport links, but heavy juggernauts still cause problems in the town.
